newsitem.title: GERMANY: Intel sees Internet transforming business.
newsitem.headline: Intel sees Internet transforming business.

text.p: The Internet is transforming the way many industries do business, but Europe is "way behind" in taking advantage of the changes, Intel Corp chief Andy Grove said on Monday.
Electronic mail, video conferencing and other Internet applications have injected a "texture of immediacy" in the way many American and Asian companies do business, Grove told a news conference.

"These applications let you react in minutes and hours instead of the the time frame of days. In that sense, Europe is way behind," said Grove, who will deliver a similar message next week in a keynote address at the World Economic Forum in Switzerland.
"I would be very concerned if our company was like that," he said, adding that many American companies were forced to develop new business models during lean years in the 1980s.
"My biggest concern for Europe is that its companies operate like oldline U.S. companies did 10 years ago," Grove told journalists. "Internet is a break in the way business is done."

Europe may face even tougher competition from Asian firms, he said. "The Asian economies are the children of the '90s. These companies are using information technology to their competitive advantage."

Europe has about 10 million to 15 million users of the Internet -- a global computer network through which users can send messages and access data sources. That is half as many Internet users as the United States, Grove said.
The number in Europe was expected to more than triple by the year 2000.
Over the next several years, the Internet would completely revolutionise the way many industries do business, he said.

Telecommunications companies would have to adapt their businesses to provide phone calls over the Internet at a fraction of the cost of regular calls. "This could become a dominant part of the telephone business," Grove said.

The Internet also gives magazines, television broadcasters, movie producers and music companies a means of delivering their products directly to consumers -- without retail stores, distrubutors or packaged products, Grove said.
Internet advertising generated $312 million in revenues in the U.S. last year, and was seen growing to $5 billion by 2000, according to market researchers.
As an example, he pointed to the software industry, which is more and more delivering computer programs directly over the Internet instead of through mail order or retail outlets.
"This allows new companies ot enter the marketplace and reach millions of customers almost overnight," he said.

Intel, which is the world's leading producer of computer micro-processors, posted a 45 percent increase in 1996 income to $5.16 billion. Grove said computer chip power should keep increasing at its torrid pace for the foreseeable future.
For more than two decades, the power of PCs has doubled about every 18 months. "There is no reason to think this performance growth rate is going to slow down in the forseeable future," Grove said.
